paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments receiving combination therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls (vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle).

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup of the retrospective cohort who received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup of the retrospective cohort who were unvaccinated.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
